hints_html:
Notice that the integrand (the function you are integrating) is a product of two functions, and so there is a particular method of integration which you might want to try.

Use integration by parts.

Notice that the integrand (the function you are integrating) is a
product of two functions, and so there is a particular method of
integration which you might want to try.
hints_raw:
Notice that the integrand (the function you are integrating) is a product of two functions, and so there is a particular method of integration which you might want to try.
Use <b>integration by parts</b>.
question: 1 (h)
sols_html:
We will evaluate this integral using integration by parts. The integration by parts formula says that the following holds:

\[\begin{aligned} \int u\,dv = uv - \int v\,du.\end{aligned}\]

If we let

\[\begin{aligned} u = \ln(x), \quad dv = \frac{1}{x^{7}}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

then we have

\[\begin{aligned} du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx, \quad v = -\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}\end{aligned}\]

and we can use the integration by parts formula to write

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{\ln(x)}{x^{7}}\,dx &= \ln(x)\cdot \left(-\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}\right) - \int \left(-\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}\right)\frac{1}{x}\,dx\\ &= -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} + \int \frac{1}{6x^{7}}\,dx \\ &= -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} - \frac{1}{36x^{6}} + C\end{aligned}\]

where \(C\) is a constant of integration.

Therefore,\(\quad{\color{blue}\int \frac{\ln(x)}{x^{7}}\,dx = -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} - \frac{1}{36x^{6}} + C }\)
sols_raw:
We will evaluate this integral using <b>integration by parts</b>. The integration by parts formula says that the following holds:
:<math>
\int u\,dv = uv - \int v\,du.
</math>
If we let
:<math>
u = \ln(x), \quad dv = \frac{1}{x^{7}}\,dx
</math>
then we have
:<math>
du = \frac{1}{x}\,dx, \quad v = -\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}
</math>
and we  can use the integration by parts formula to write
:<math>
\begin{align}
\int \frac{\ln(x)}{x^{7}}\,dx &= \ln(x)\cdot \left(-\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}\right) - \int \left(-\frac{1}{6}x^{-6}\right)\frac{1}{x}\,dx\\
&= -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} + \int \frac{1}{6x^{7}}\,dx \\
&= -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} - \frac{1}{36x^{6}} + C
\end{align}
</math>
where <math>C</math> is a constant of integration. 

<font style="color:blue;"> Therefore,</font><math>
\quad{\color{blue}
\int \frac{\ln(x)}{x^{7}}\,dx = -\frac{\ln(x)}{6x^{6}} - \frac{1}{36x^{6}} + C
}
</math>

Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Evaluate \(\displaystyle \int\frac{\ln(x)}{x^7}\,dx\) .
